jeopardy_round: THINGS TO DO ON A RAINY DAY

(1, 1).clue: Put together one of these; the 4,000-piece world map should take you a while

(2, 1).clue: It's a 5-letter word meaning a distinguishing characteristic

(3, 1).clue: It's set on an island during World War II:"S.P."

(4, 1).clue: Ho ho ho!  Named after a variety of large peas, this character first appeared in ads in 1928

(6, 1).clue: Type of graph using vertical rectangles to show the frequency of specific items in a set of data

(1, 2).clue: Assume the warrior pose, mountain pose or seated twist while practicing this

(2, 2).clue: Varieties include Mead's 6" X 9" 100-sheet & Sony's Xperia Z2

(5, 2).clue: The Victoria Falls Hotel, just south of the falls

(2, 3).clue: An area of land; you also have a digestive one

(3, 3).clue: Ease on down the road with this musical:"T.W."

(4, 3).clue: A schoolkid won $5 for designing this top-hatted Planter's icon

(6, 3).clue: An architect's face-on drawing of a building is an elevation; a top-down view is this simple 4-letter word

(2, 4).clue: Proverbially, it's where you'll find a "tempest"

(3, 4).clue: Marvin Hamlisch composed the music for it:"A.C.L."

(4, 4).clue: Appropriately, a brainstorming session produced the little girl under an umbrella for this brand

(6, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew shows a globe and map on the monitor.)  The curved surface of the Earth, represented on a flat sheet of paper, is called this; the Mercator one here is from the 19th century

(1, 5).clue: Warm up with a cup of green tea while watching a double feature of this director's "Ran" & "Seven Samurai"

(2, 5).clue: It's a person with no fixed residence

(4, 5).clue: This StarKist spokes-tuna looks as hip as ever in his signature glasses & beret

(6, 5).clue: Renaissance artists developed the linear type of this, using converging parallels to make 2D look like 3D

(1, 1).clue: Tiny blood vessels; also, tiny channels that carry bile

(2, 1).clue: This 1990 11-hour Ken Burns documentary made good use of photos & writings of soldiers

(3, 1).clue: To this first name belong the spoils

(4, 1).clue: The Annapolis Convention met in 1786 & concluded that the document called these Articles wasn't going to cut it

(5, 1).clue: Yudansha is a term used to describe students who have acquired this rank in karate

(1, 2).clue: Orbicularis oculi palpebral muscles close this piece of tissue, palpebra in medical speak

(2, 2).clue: Sort of "Top Gun" meets "Law & Order", this 1995-2005 show mixed legal, military & personal stories

(4, 2).clue: In 1792 Robert Thomas first published this almanac about New England life &, of course, the weather

(5, 2).clue: This rank in British peerage below a marquis & above a viscount is also a first name

(6, 2).clue: The socially alienated Meursault is the title character of this Camus novel

(1, 3).clue: The name of these heart valves mean "half moon"

(2, 3).clue: 4 women & 1 man share the common bond of loving someone in the military on this Lifetime series

(4, 3).clue: It's Philadelphia in the 1750s & what has Ben Franklin foisted on us now?  Street lamps powered by this animal product

(5, 3).clue: It was the highest military rank held by both Erwin Rommel & Bernard Montgomery

(6, 3).clue: In 2014 a friend said, I found your lost-since-the-50s novel "Go Set the Watchman"; age 88, she said, "It's Go Set a Watchman"

(1, 4).clue: The endometrium is the tissue that lines this organ

(2, 4).clue: The Vietnam War was seen through the eyes of nurses near the front lines on this Dana Delany show

(3, 4).clue: Tom Canty, at the start of a Twain novel

(4, 4).clue: In the 1780s this "Gouverneur" proposed the decimal monetary system & devised the name "cent" for the basic coin

(6, 4).clue: Liam O'Flaherty wrote this novel whose title refers to one who tells the authorities about a comrade
